results.title: Challenge in the desert
results.creator_credit: United Nations. Dept. of Public Information
results.brief_description: After assisting Libya to gain independence in 1951, the United Nations has continued to give technical assistance to develop the country. As much of the land is unsuitable for cultivation, future prosperity depends on improving crops. Cooperatives for the citrus fruit and sheep industries have been formed and reforestation and irrigation projects are under way.

results.title: Challenge in the air
results.creator_credit: British Movietone News and Central Office of Information
results.brief_description: The Society of British Aircraft Constructor’s 17th Flying Display and Exhibition at Farnborough in 1956, which featured some of the latest developments in British aircraft and aero-engines. Among aircraft on view was the Fairey “Delta 2”, in which Peter Twiss had set up the world air speed record for Britain. Engines were a special feature of the show and demonstrations of the de Havilland “Super Sprite” and Napier “Scorpion” liquid propellent rocket motors are seen.

results.title: Challenge for change
results.creator_credit: Bill Reid and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 102 of Series “Challenge for change/Societe nouvelle”.
‘Challenge for change’ is a community based government program. Its objective is to shed light on social problems through the production of films. What is Challenge for Change? What happens with children from deprived areas when they are given a free hand to make their own films? Who can be a better voice for Indian needs and aspirations than an Indian film crew? How angry are the black people with the way society treats them? How do government representatives react to social change and the role of the Challenge for Change program? Can a film project serve as a cohesive agent and catalyst for change within a community, and at the same time serve as a means of communication with government? What is community organizing? What role can film play in participatory democracy? Does controversy lead to violence? How useful are the films from Challenge for Change going to be? This film has some of the answers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Reid and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Chairmen = L Age de Chaise
results.creator_credit: Gaston Sarault, ONF | NFB and Jean Bedard
results.brief_description: An allegory of contemporary society, this animation film shows a society where man has lost his freedom in the struggle to wrest recognition from the very society that is restricting his freedom. The chair is the symbol of success. Without a chair, man is a social outcast. Highly critical of our way of life and modern society, the film questions the present and the future. Complex and innovative animation techniques emphasize the message. A film without words. (Awards: Annecy; Oberhausen; Chicago)

results.title: Chains of circumstance
results.brief_description: Three case histories of poverty show the work of the Freemasons’ Benevolent Institution in New South Wales. The Institution was founded in 1880 as a means of helping the aged, invalid and distressed. From a system of voluntary subscriptions, annuities are granted to those who need help.

results.title: Chains of arcady
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Landscape with figures: the art of Australia”.
One of a series in which Robert Hughes surveys Australia’s art from the time of the first fleet to the present day. Covers mainly the convict artists of Australia’s early days. Discusses the works of Thomas Watling, Joseph Lycett, Conrad Martens, John Glover, William Gould, Augustus Earle and Thomas Boch. Commentary by Robert Hughes. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Chain reaction
results.brief_description: A silent film without subtext about one’s bad humour on others. An office manager whose wife spills the tea on his morning paper upsets his wife, their children and his subordinates at work. No other credits available.
